nodes.text: The time-average growth optimisation view (ergodicity economics) corresponds to expected utility theory when the utility function is the ergodicity transformation of the wealth dynamics; therefore expected-utility maximisation can be interpreted as growth-rate maximisation under appropriate wealth processes

Ergodicity economics (EE) postulates agents maximise the time-average growth rate of wealth (growth optimality) by modelling wealth as stochastic processes (wealth dynamics) and using time averages relevant to single trajectories

Expected utility theory (EUT) models agents as maximising the expectation value of a non-linear transformation of wealth (utility function) over possible outcomes, treating utility as a psychological construct fitted to observed choices

Central technical result: EUT is equivalent to optimisation over time if and only if the utility u follows an additive stochastic process with stationary increments, taken here as a Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW, so that the time-average growth rate equals the expectation rate of change of u

Method/result: For any invertible utility function u(x) that is twice differentiable, applying Ito's lemma to du = a_u dt + b_u dW yields an explicit stochastic differential equation (SDE) for wealth dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW, establishing a mapping from utility to wealth dynamics

Method/result (inverse): Given an Ito wealth process dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW, necessary and sufficient consistency conditions (relations between a_x and b_x) determine whether a corresponding utility u exists with constant a_u and b_u; if so u can be constructed by integrating b_u / b_x(x)
Example/evidence: Linear utility u(x)=x corresponds to additive wealth dynamics (Brownian motion) dx = a_u dt + b_u dW, showing correspondence reproduces additive case

Example/evidence: Logarithmic utility u(x)=ln x corresponds to multiplicative (geometric Brownian) wealth dynamics dx = x[(a_u + 0.5 b_u^2) dt + b_u dW], reproducing Kelly/known multiplicative growth results; square-root utility u(x)=sqrt(x) maps to a mixed additive-multiplicative SDE with sqrt noise amplitude

Example/result: For the constructed exponential utility u(x)=b_u exp(x)+C the derived wealth SDE dx = (a_u/b_u e^{-x} - 0.5 e^{-2x}) dt + e^{-x} dW yields a wealth distribution computable from the normal distribution of u(t), producing heavy-left-tail and sticky high-wealth behavior

Conclusion/implication: The correspondence provides a theoretical basis for choosing utility functions from exogenous wealth dynamics and predicts that observed risk preferences depend on underlying wealth dynamics rather than fixed psychological traits
Evidence: Experimental studies with controllable wealth dynamics support the prediction that dynamics are strong determinants of preferences, favoring EE predictions over EUT with fixed preferences

Limitation/assumption: The equivalence requires invertible (hence effectively unbounded) utility functions and wealth processes that admit an ergodicity transformation; processes that do not admit such a transformation cannot be given a dynamical EUT interpretation and may be pathological for this framework

Conclusion: Interpreting utility as an ergodicity transformation reframes non-linear utility functions as encoding the non-linear effects of temporal fluctuations, removing the need to posit innate psychological risk aversion and enabling mechanistic prediction of apparent preferences from wealth dynamics
